ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to work as a team in a real-life project. Apply different skills I have gained throughout my college career to make an impact.
I learned a lot about gender inequality in Costa Rica!

I learned how to coordinate tasks and establish timelines within a group project. We had to overcome several hurdles including maintaining contact with each other so that we could conduct research for and build multiple deliverables. It provided insight into the background work that one would do to instruct a client on how to improve their organization(s) or build out their initiative(s).
team work skills and taking on leadership roles/taking initiative; how to work with a client (ups and downs); in depth knowledge of the topic

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had a great group and an amazing faculty, so no weaknesses except for some bureaucracy with the org we were working with.
Professor Palmieri was very engaging and such a great mentor for his students.

Strengths: teamwork, delegating tasks, building out the deliverables, improving ones presentation skills, learning how to communicate with ones team, learning about non-communicable diseases, conducting in-depth research/analysis, examining different global settings, guest lectures, and learning about terms used in the global health field.
Weaknesses: more in-depth discussions each week could have been appreciated.

strengths: we had a lot of autonomy over the direction of the project; gave me leadership/taking initiative experience I wouldn't have received otherwise; professor was engaged and always willing to help 

weaknesses: felt a little too unstructured; wasn't sure of expectations at some points during the project; not enough mechanisms to keep all team members accountable

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminars felt a bit long sometimes but the small class size was really great.
Each weeks seminars were insightful, but there could have been more communication between the students and those they would be serving through the project.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Its required for global affairs but I would take this course again! Professor Palmieri is great
requirement for global major; the professor for this particular project is great and really invested in you
